instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to propose a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree?
Output: The related study used visible spectrum and nir spectrum to propose a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to propose a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree?
Output: Black-and-white correction and multiplicative scatter correction were used for spectral feature processing in the proposed non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree.

instruction: What metric was chosen to propose a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree and how accurate was it?
Output: The metric chosen to propose a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree was the extreme learning machine (ELM) model. The accuracy of the ELM-classification model in classifying the pollution degree was reported to be 95% for NaCl, 97.5% for CaSO4, and 97.5% for mixed NaCl-CaSO4 samples.

instruction: How was the extreme learning machine (ELM) used to classify the pollution degree of test samples in the study proposing a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree based on hyperspectral technique?
Output: In the study proposing a non-contact detection method of insulator pollution degree based on hyperspectral technique, the extreme learning machine (ELM) was used to classify the pollution degree of test samples. A multiclassification model of ELM was built using the hyperspectral curves obtained from the region of interest (ROI) of corrected images. The ELM model was trained using the hyperspectral data from samples with different pollution degrees, and it was able to accurately and rapidly classify the pollution degree of test samples. The classification accuracy of the ELM model for NaCl, CaSO4, and mixed NaCl-CaSO4 pollution degrees reached 95%, 97.5%, and 97.5% respectively.

instruction: Can the hyperspectral technique be used as a superior alternative to traditional methods for the non-contact detection of insulator pollution degree in the related study?
Output: Yes, the hyperspectral technique can be considered as a superior alternative to traditional methods for the non-contact detection of insulator pollution degree in the related study. The results of the study show that the hyperspectral technique, when combined with a multiclassification model of extreme learning machine (ELM), can accurately and rapidly classify the pollution degree of insulator umbrellas with different types of pollution. The classification accuracy achieved by the ELM model based on hyperspectral curves data is high, reaching 95% for NaCl, 97.5% for CaSO4, and 97.5% for mixed NaCl-CaSO4. This demonstrates the considerable potential of hyperspectral technique for non-contact detection of insulator pollution degree.
